It will go as the crow flies, over hillside and ridge, and crossing the Waioweka River 24 times in 20 miles. Soon it will be farewell to lamps, candles and diesel plants in the Wyo Eka.
This is Rotaruas Sports Dome.
Though a large building, its ceiling has no vertical supports.
It's done by lamination.
These large laminated wood arches are self-supporting.
There's enough room underneath for a football field.
Ordinary timber couldn't do it, but stir in some glue and you've got a different picture altogether.

making stringers for a new bridge near Tipuki, the first in New Zealand to use laminated timber.
After these pieces of softwood have been planed and the ends beveled, they're glued, placed in scarf joints and put under pressure.
37 of these boards will be glued into a beam 60 feet long and 5 feet wide.
The pieces of timber are now ready to be laminated.
Glue is spread on the boards and they are sandwiched into beams.
Unity is strength, but it needs strength in the first place to get that unity.

laminated timber girders.
Lamination now makes it possible to use softwoods where only hardwoods could be used before,
and engineers are eager to see how they shape up under these new conditions.

abutments has been completed and all it remains is to position the beams and roll

stringers into position on steel pins. These stringers are as strong as structural

Once the beams are in position, it's only a day's work to put the decking on.

Quick work if you can do it, and with laminated timber you can.

in 1956 in the Wightake Valley there were just barren hills and valleys running a few sheep
and some surveyors in their constant search for hydroelectric sites.
A year later after tests and designs were finalized, approval was given to start the Benmore
scheme to keep up with the increasing demand for electricity.
Houses for the labor force from completed Roxburgh made the new construction town of Otamata.
By 1960 the completion of the diversion tunnel marked the end of the first stage.
Three years after work started, the course of the Waitaki River was changed forever.
Heavy machinery followed, dumping to make the 16 million cubic yard earth dam, a fair pile of dirt in any language.
On their best days, the dam rose by 18 inches a day to a total of 365 feet high and nearly a half mile long.
In 1961, the plan to hitch the north to the south for power transmission was given approval. So along with the construction of the generators, capable of producing 540 megawatts
were added converters for changing alternating current to direct current
to make Benmore the biggest direct current project in the world.
Over the hills and plains, pylons traverse the 380 miles from Benmore to Fighting Bay at the Cook Strait end of the South Island.
From the North Island, converted freighters contend with the vagaries of Cook Strait to lay their multi-million pound cargo.
It's a long job waiting for suitable weather.
The three 25-mile cables are the longest and heaviest ever made in one continuous length.
Two cables complete the circuit for carrying 600 megawatts.
The third is a spare. With the islands linked, Hayward's just north of Wellington converts the direct current back to alternating current for general use.
In the country's dams and generating stations, Benmore's the greatest. Finally, in May, 1965, the 48 million pound engineering achievement was ready for opening by the Prime Minister, Mr. Holyoke.
I pressed this Brutton, which will commence, officially commence, the inter-island power transmission from this great and unique Benmore Power Station.
